div.p: My friendly greetings along with all that I can offer in honor, love, and goodness, first of all. Venerable, highly learned, especially honorable, gracious, dear sir, I have received your letter, thank you most sincerely for your effort and work and am very satisfied to send my nephew to Mr. Walther. However, since I intend to ride home, I will inform my brother-in-law of this and consult with him when we want to send him to Zurich. With this, I commend myself to you, faithfully praying to Almighty God that He may keep you in His divine protection.
Dated at Baden, August 7, 1548. Your willing servant Hans Wunderlich.
To the venerable, highly learned Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, proclaimer of the holy word in Zurich, my especially honorable, dear sir.
